Isabelle is 34 years old; she is married and the mother of three children. She is a dressmaker by training. Isabelle’s secondary business involves selling cloth, jewelry, soaps, and aluminum utensils. To meet her needs and those of her family, she has dedicated herself to this second business. Basically, she buys her goods at Dantokpa, the grand international marketplace of Benin. She distributes these goods on credit to customers who ordered them; every five days, she comes around to collect. Isabelle has already benefited from an initial ALIDé loan that she has repaid. She’s requesting a second loan from ALIDé to bolster her working capital in order to respond better to customer demands.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy six 12-meter bolts of cloth, ten boxes of BF soap, and some jewelry to sell

loans.name: Sapolaneh Group

texts.en:
These are members of the Sapolaneh group who are requesting a loan of Le 1,200,000 for each to enable them to further strengthen their businesses. With this loan amount, they can buy more goods to add to their stalls. This will attract more customers to their stalls.

Aminata B. (second from left) is the leader of this group. Aminata was born in Mile Ninety-One in northern Sierra Leone, twenty-five years ago. She is married to a driver and they have one child who is in class one. Aminata has sold cottons, chains, watches, etc., for the past five years. She will invest this loan in her business.

loans.use: To invest in her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Ce crédit sera utilisé pour l'achat de la machine de vulgarisation

loans.name: Akosua

texts.en:
Akosua is forty-five years old. She is divorced and has given birth to five children: four sons and a daughter. All of her children are still in school. As a single parent, she says she works very hard to be able to provide for her family. Akosua lives with her children in a rented apartment in Dunkwa in the central region of Ghana.

Akosua is a trader, trading in cereals such as maize, beans, etc. She buys her goods from the nearby communities and sells at the local market. She also supplies to food vendors and other retailers in her community. She has been in business for over ten years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy cereals in bulk

loans.name: Carmelle

texts.fr: Carmelle est née le 10 avril 1980 à Porto-Novo, Capitale Administrative et Politique de la République du BENIN. Carmelle est célibataire sans enfants et vit à Cotonou, Capitale Économique de la République du Bénin. Carmelle vend des tissus sur commande. En effet, Carmelle distribue à crédit des tissus à sa clientèle qui en fait la demande. Carmelle passe quelques jours après pour colleter ses fonds selon l’échéancier de paiement arrêté avec ses clients. C’est au Ghana, pays frontaliers au Bénin que Carmelle achète ses tissus. Carmelle a besoins de plus de moyens financiers qu’elle en possède actuellement pour répondre efficacement à la demande de sa clientèle. Alors, Carmelle sollicite le soutient financier de ALIDé pour mieux satisfaire ses clients.
texts.en:
Carmelle was born on April 10, 1980 in Porto-Novo, the administrative and political capital of the Republic of Benin. She is unmarried and has no children. She lives in Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Benin. Carmelle sells cloth by special order. Basically, she distributes cloth on credit to customers ordering from her. Later on, she comes around to collect, according to a payment schedule settled with her customers. Ghana, a nation near Benin, is where she buys her cloth. Carmelle needs more financing than she currently has for responding appropriately to customer demands. She is therefore requesting financial support from ALIDé to satisfy her customers better.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy two 12-meter bolts of WAX cloth and ten 12-meter bolts of HI-TARGET cloth

loans.name: Abena

texts.en:
Abena is fifty-five years old. She is married and has given birth to nine children, all of whom are still in school. Abena works very hard to support her husband to be able to provide for the family. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Dunkwa in the Central Region of Ghana.

Abena is a trader, trading in vegetables – tomatoes. She buys boxes of tomatoes from the nearby communities and sells on a table at the local market. She also supplies to food vendors and other retailers in her community. Abena has been in business for over thirty years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy tomatoes in bulk

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica started her beef sales eight years ago and sells in a community market where she lives. She prepares and serves her customers with very tasty and good quality beef and, because of that, many customers buy from her stand. She is now 38 years old and married with two girls who are currently in school.

Monica takes delivery of beef from Kumasi in the Ashanti region of Ghana. She wants to use the loan to buy an increased stock of beef to make increased sales and income to support her children’s education and her business growth. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy an increased stock of beef

loans.name: Ayichetou

texts.fr: Cette dame est mariée et est mère d’un enfant. Pour aider financièrement son mari soudeur à couvrir les besoins de son foyer, elle a démarré en 2006 la vente de sacs de charbon de bois dans son quartier Agoè Cacavéli à Lomé. Elle a besoin de renouveler son stock ; c’est pour cette raison qu’elle sollicite un prêt de WAGES pour acheter 15 petits sacs et 09 sacs moyens. Elle a une clientèle qui lui est fidèle.
texts.en:
This is a lady who is married and the mother of one child. To help her husband, a welder, to cover the costs of household needs, she started off by selling sacks of charcoal in 2006 in her district, Agoè Cacavéli, in Lomé. She needs to renew her stock; this is the reason she’s requesting a loan from WAGES to buy 13 small sacks of charcoal and 9 mid-size sacks. She has a customer base which is very loyal.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Masorie Progressive Union Group

texts.en:
These are members of the Masorie Progressive Union group. This is the second loan this group is accessing from SMT/Kiva. The members have experienced a vast improvement in their businesses as a result of the first loan and they are therefore requesting a new loan, having successfully repaid the previous one. With the help of this loan, they will be able to further expand their businesses and make better profits so that they can look after themselves and their children.

Umu S. K. (left) is the leader of this group. She sells palm-oil, rice, groundnuts (peanuts), and other locally produced food items. She has been a businesswoman for more than ten years.

Umu is now forty-two years of age. She was born in Kamakwe but now lives in Masorie village where she is married. She has two children: one is now a driver and the other has just taken the West Africa Senior Secondary Schools examinations.

loans.use: To invest in her business

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys is sixty years old. She is widowed and has given birth to six children: three sons and two daughters, some of whom are still in school. As a single parent, she says she works very hard to be able to provide for her family. Gladys lives with her children in a rented apartment in Dunkwa in the Central Region of Ghana.

Gladys is a trader, trading in cereals such as maize, beans, etc. She buys her goods from the nearby communities and sells at the local market. She also supplies to food vendors and other retailers in her community. Gladys has been in business for over twenty years and wants a loan to buy cereals and other foodstuffs in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy cereals in bulk

loans.name: Estrellas De Oro Group

texts.es: Grupo “Estrellas D. Oro” esta conformado por doce socias 80% mujeres Y 20 % varones que radican en la zona D. Alto San Pedro, es un grupo que ingresa a su primer ciclo demostrando unidad y solidaridad en sus reuniones previas. Las socias en su mayoría se dedican a la venta D. verduras, ropa, víveres y otros pero lo comercializan en el interior (Nor Yungas - Zud Yungas), por que lo consideran un mercado poco explotado y con mayores oportunidades D. venta D. los productos; otras D. las socias se dedican a la peluquería contando con su salón D. belleza ubicados en lugares estratégicos donD. cuentan con clientes leales a su trabajo;  entre ellas se tiene socias que confeccionan chompas, mantas hechas a mano las cuales son comercializan en empresas que exportan o realizan venta local, otras ofrecen sus productos en ferias o ambulan, sus productos son relativamente económicos con costo mínimo D. su material D. trabajo; entre otro los socios se dedican al transporte público los cuales requieren del crédito para la compra D. llantas y repuestos. El mercado actual se encuentra saturado D. productos similares pero las socias saben como salir adelante llevando sus productos al interno o exterior del país. La socias van cursando su primer ciclo pero ya cuentan con experiencia en grupos solidarios por lo se comprometen a dar todo D. si para salir adelante con responsabilidad y unidad.Por los continuos viajes alguno D. las socias no se presentaron pero mandaron a sus esposos a la reunion.
texts.en:
The group, “Estrellas D. Oro” ('Stars of gold') is maD. up of twelve members, 80% of which are women, 20% of which are men, who live in the zone of Alto San Pedro. This group is going into their first cycle having demonstrated their unity and solidarity in previous meetings. The majority of the members dedicate themselves to the sale of vegetables, clothing, provisions and other things that they sell in the interior of the country (Nor Yungas - Zud Yungas) as it is not a well exploited market and offers great opportunities to sell products. Other members dedicate themselves to hairdressing, as they have beauty salons located in strategic places where they have a lot of regular clients. Between them, there are members that make sweaters and handmaD. blankets which they sell to export businesses or locally. Others offer their products in markets or in the street, and their products are economically maD., using low cost working materials. Other members dedicate themselves to public transport, and they need the credit to buy tyres and spare parts. The current market is saturated with similar products, but the members know how to move forward, taking their products to the interior and exterior of the country. The members are in their first cycle but they can already count on experience in such groups which is why they promise to give everything to move forward with responsability and unity. Due to the journeys they must take, some of the members couldn't be at the meeting, but sent their partners instead.


Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operations' capital/capital de Operaciones

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
Theresa is a 45-year-old woman. She is married and is the mother of two children, all of whom are in school in the community where they live.

Theresa is a food vendor and sells “waakye” with gravy stew at the market center. Waakye is prepared from rice grains together with beans. Many Ghanaians enjoyed waakye as breakfast, lunch and supper.

Theresa started her operation about fifteen years ago in order to take care of her home. Her food production is on a low scale because of inadequate funds to support her business. She wants to use the loan to buy more meat, vegetables and bags of rice to increase her efficiency by producing in larger quantities. She believes this will help expand her business and raise more income to support and to provide for her family and to finance her children education. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, vegetables, meat and firewood

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Mrs. Rebecca C., 47 years old, is married with seven children and lives in Brgy. Banquerohan, Cadiz City, Negros Occidental where she is the Barangay (Village) Health Worker. Mrs. C. joined NWTF-Project Dungganon because she dreamed of improving the quality of life of her family. For almost six years, Mrs. C. has operated a general store that sells an almost complete line of household commodities to her neighbors. In addition to her general store, she also sells fish to the community, and these business activities earn her an average of PHP 39,000 per month - enough to sustain her family of nine. For her 18th loan, she is requesting Php 25,000 which she plans to invest in expanding the operations of her business. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the call of not just a few, but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Olinto Valle Group

texts.es:
El grupo Olinto Valle es originario del centro de Masaya, sus integrantes son Juana Adela C. B., Rosana Gertrudis P. F. y Lilian Francisca S. D., tres microempresarias con alto potencial, dedicación y destreza para el comercio.

La coordinadora del grupo es Juana Adela quien trabaja en la venta de prendas de plata y enchapadas en oro desde hace más de 5 años, tiempo durante el cual se ha desempeñado eficientemente y ha extendido su mercado de una manera eficaz.  Inicio sacando las prendas al crédito con una señora que viajaba a panamá, pero con el tiempo se dio cuenta que era mejor si solicitaba un crédito para comprar las prendas directamente. Así conoció ADIM y .los resultados han sido grandiosos. Actualmente tiene clientes en los Bancos, la Alcaldía y otras instituciones donde distribuye su mercadería.

Su crédito pretende invertirlo en la compra de más productos. Está iniciando el segundo ciclo de crédito y espera seguir adelante ya que su mayor sueño es poner una tienda en su casa donde pueda ofertar sus prendas.

Rosana distribuye zapatos y ropa en general, compra los encargos en El mercado Oriental de Managua (Principal centro de comercio, donde se encuentran los productos al por mayor y a mas bajos precios) y los vende en Masaya. Y Lilian quien distribuye cosméticos de la Zermat y de la Avon.
texts.en:
The Olinto Valle Group originates from central Masaya. The members are Juana Adela C. B., Rosana Gertrudis P. F., and Lilian Francisca S. D.. These three micro-entrepreneurs possess great potential, dedication, and business acumen.

Juana Adela is the group coordinator. She has been selling gold and silver jewelry for more than 5 years. During this time, she has worked efficiently and has been able to expand her market with great effect. She started buying jewelry on credit from a woman who traveled to Panama, but she eventually realized that she was better off taking out a loan and buying the jewelry directly. She learned about ADIM, and her results have turned out great. Her existing customers are bank employees, municipal employees, and those who work at other institutions where she distributes her merchandise.

Juana Adela intends to use her loan to buy more products. She is starting her second loan cycle and expects to succeed. Her greatest dream is to open a store in her home where she can sell her jewelry.

Rosana sells shoes and clothing. She picks up her orders from the Managua Eastern Market (the main center of trade, where products are offered wholesale and prices are lower) and then sells her merchandise in Masaya. Lilian is a distributor of cosmetics made by Zermat and Avon.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase jewelry & other merchandise

loans.name: Dora

texts.en:
Dora is 42 years old, is divorced, and is the mother of a girl who is currently breastfeeding. As a single mother she always works hard to provide for, and provide health support for, her child. She is determined to provide for her child through hard work and commitment.

Dora sells cosmetics, clothing materials, traveling bags, etc. in the market center of her community where she lives. She has been in business for close to thirty years now. She says the selling of cosmetics is very lucrative and therefore she wants to expand her inventory to enable her to make a good income to sponsor her child’s education. She is very sure that your loan support will bring her the desired results.

loans.use: To expand her inventory

loans.name: Las Estrellitas Group

texts.es: El grupo “Las Estrellitas” esta representado por la señora Felicia y conformada por 14 miembros los cuales asumen la garantía solidaria y mancomunada en la que la mayoría del grupo ya cuenta con experiencia gracias a créditos similares con otras entidades semejantes a la fundación Agrocapital. Las socias se dedican a venta de comida, venta de refrescos,  pastillas, tiendas de abarrotes, los varones se dedica al transporte público de pasajeros. La competencia a nivel comercial es alta pero la socias tienen mucha experiencia y saben como sacar adelante sus negocios ofreciendo productos variados y de buena calidad. El crédito esta destinado a la compra y adquisición de mercadería como pastillas al por mayor, abarrotes, insumos y herramientas como repuestos para sus vehículos  para incrementar sus ingresos que se refleja en el bien estar de sus familias y la buena educación de sus hijos. La socias van cursando su primer ciclo pero ya cuentan con experiencia en grupos solidarios por lo se comprometen a dar todo de si para salir adelante con responsabilidad y unidad.
texts.en:
The group “Las Estrellitas” is led by Sra. Felicia and consists of 14 members. They all assume the joint solidarity guarantee since many of the group members have previous experience working with other entities similar to Fundación Agrocapital. Most of the female members have retail businesses selling food, soft drinks, medicines, and groceries. The men have businesses in the public transportation sector. The level of business competition is high, but most of the members are experienced enough to know that they must offer a variety of high quality products and services in order to succeed.

This group loan will be used to acquire merchandise at wholesale, supplies, tools, and vehicle spare parts. This will help the members increase their incomes, which is then reflected in the improved well-being of their families and education for their children. The members are working together on their first loan cycle, but since they have experience with other solidarity groups, they promise to move forward with responsibility and unity.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Kande

texts.en:
Kande is forty years old. She is widowed and has given birth to four children: three sons and a daughter. All of her children are still in school. As a single parent, she says she works very hard to be able to provide for her family. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in Dunkwa in the Central Region of Ghana.

Kande is a trader, selling textiles and jewelry. She buys her goods from Kumasi and sells at the local market. She also hawks (sells door-to-door) and treks to sell. She has been in business for seven years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy goods in bulk to expand her business

loans.name: Essivi

texts.fr: Essivi est née vers 1959 à Cotonou, Capitale Économique de la République du Bénin. Essivi est veuve et mère de deux enfants. Essivi vend des articles de mercerie, des fournitures scolaires et des divers (Bonbons, biscuits, boîtes de lait, de sardines, de tomates, de sucres, les pâtes alimentaires, les savons de lessive, de vaisselle et de toilette, piles, bougies, etc.)dans sa boutique construite près de son domicile. Essivi achète ses articles à Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin. Cette activité que Essivi mène lui permet de subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants. Essivi a déjà bénéficié d’un crédit à ALIDé pour développer son commerce. Essivi a bien remboursé ce crédit et sollicite un deuxième crédit, toujours pour mieux développer son activité.

loans.use: Achat d’articles de mercerie, de fournitures scolaires et de divers.

loans.name: Manfredo Cuellar Group

texts.es: El grupo “Manfredo C.” esta representado por la señora Betty y conformado 13 miembros  los cuales han demostrado responsabilidad y honestidad en sus reuniones. Una gran mayoría de las socias se dedican a la venta de productos como Comida, abarrotes, cosméticos por catalogo, ropa y a actividades como el transporte público de pasajeros, construcción de viviendas y empleadas domesticas. La competencia a nivel comercial es alta pero la socias tienen mucha experiencia y saben como sacar adelante sus negocios ofreciendo productos variados y de buena calidad. El destino del crédito es para aumentar su capital de trabajo y emprender pequeños negocios para incrementar más sus ganancias, que se traduce en mejorar la calidad de vida de sus familias que día a día van mejorando mas, por ello están muy agradecidos por la confianza depositada para seguir trabajando con mas ganas. La socias van cursando su primer ciclo pero ya cuentan con experiencia en grupos solidarios por lo se comprometen a dar todo de si para salir adelante con responsabilidad y unidad.
texts.en:
The ‘Manfredo C.’ group is represented by Sra. Betty. It is comprised of thirteen members who have demonstrated responsibility and honesty in their meetings. A large majority of the members earn their living selling such products as food, groceries, cosmetics by catalogue, clothing, or by activities such as public transportation of passengers, house construction, and domestic service. There is a lot of competition, but the members have a great deal of experience and know how to make their businesses successful: by offering a variety of good-quality products. They plan to use the loan as working capital and start small businesses in order to generate more income. In this way they will gradually improve the quality of life of their families. For this reason they are very grateful for the confidence shown in them and will carry on working with more enthusiasm. The members are taking out their first loan, but they already talk knowledgeably about group solidarity. They promise to work together responsibly and make every effort to help each other succeed.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Nemé

texts.fr: Cette femme vend des sacs de charbon de bois, ce qui lui permet de se prendre en charge et d’assurer l’éducation de son enfant. Elle est très connue à Agoè Zongo à Lomé où elle approvisionne tout le quartier et ses environs. Pour éviter une pénurie de charbon de bois, elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 10 sacs moyens de charbon de bois, 12 petits sacs de charbon de bois et assurer aussi les frais de transport vers le lieu d’approvisionnement. Cette femme n’est pas mariée.
texts.en:
This is a woman who sells sacks of charcoal, which enables her to care for and educate her child. She is well-known in Agoè Zongo in Lomé, where she supplies the entire district and surrounding areas. To prevent a shortage of charcoal, she’s requesting a loan from WAGES to buy ten mid-size sacks of charcoal and twelve small sacks and to ensure the costs are covered for the supply run. This woman is unmarried.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Los Canastitos Group

texts.es:
El grupo los Canastitos es originario de la Ciudad de Monimbó-Masaya; cuyo  poblado está situado a una legua de Masaya. De todas las poblaciones que eran grupos chorotegas, sólo Monimbó ha mantenido la identidad étnica a través de tiempo. Se destaca por su producción de artesanías en palma y en cuero y por su raíz Folklórica.

La coordinadora del grupo es doña María de los Ángeles de 39 años de edad, trabaja en costura, negocio que inició hace varios años cuando se salió de de la Zona Franca, donde había trabajado, y con su liquidación decidió comprar una máquina de coser para iniciar su propio taller de costura.

Su crédito lo requiere para invertir en la compra de materiales y poco a poco ir ampliando su taller, y que de esta manera sus hijas aprendan a trabajar y puedan estudiar valiéndose de ésta herramienta para salir adelante.

Doña Rosa Adela T. trabaja en la elaboración de comidas y frescos en su casa y doña Ana Julia S. trabaja como costurera en su hogar.
texts.en:
The Canastitos Group originates from the city of Monimbó-Masaya, which is located one league (about 3 miles) away from Masaya. Of all the populations that descended from the Chorotega group, only the Monimbó have been able to maintain their ethnic identity over time. This is evident in the production of handcrafts made of palm leaves and leather which are rooted in folklore.

Doña María de los Ángeles is the group coordinator. She is 39 years old and works as a seamstress. She started her business several years ago when she left the Franca District, where she worked previously. Using the settlement payment from her old employer, she decided to buy a sewing machine so that she could open her own tailoring workshop.

She will use her loan to purchase materials and gradually expand her workshop. Her children will be able to work and study at the same time in order to get ahead.

Doña Rosa Adela T. works from home preparing and selling meals and beverages. Doña Ana Julia S. also works from home as a seamstress.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase materials in order to increase output

loans.name: Tamemsusor Group

texts.en:
Kadiatu S. has been a farmer and a businesswoman for many years now. She was born in a village called Domubath, near Masorie village. She is approximately 55 years old, married to a farmer from Samorie village, and they have four children who are now all grown-up. Kadiatu will invest her loan in her farm.

Kadiatu (right) is the leader of this group. They are members of the Tamensusor group of Masorie village, which is about 13 miles from Makeni. They are small scale business people and farmers. This is the second loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva. Their previous loan has made a lot of improvements in their lives and businesses. Now they want a new loan in order to further expand their businesses.

loans.use: To invest in a farm

loans.name: Clarita

texts.en: "Living in a hacienda (sugarcane plantation) with low wages and raising ten children is very hard to manage. We had plans to give our children a better future through education but then we didn't have enough resources to provide for all of them. I dreamed that maybe someday my children will lift me out of poverty. But how?" - This is the question of Mrs. Clarita K., a 55-year-old married woman who lives in Hacienda Caridad, Brgy. Luna, Cadiz City, Negros Occidental. Mrs. K. knew that the small income that her husband earned was not enough for her dream for her children. This is the reason why she decided to join NWTF-Project Dungganon - to borrow enough capital to start a business to supplement her husband's income. Using her first loan, she put up a food stall, selling different kind of fruit in the local market of Cadiz. She noticed that her business income helped her very much with the needs of her family. Her business is doing well and earns about PHP 12,000 per month. This new loan of Php 13,000 is Mrs. K.'s 9th and will be utilized for the purchase of additional inventory and as working capital. The profits from this will be used to supplement her family's income. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the call of not just a few, but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Mujeres Solidarias Group

texts.en:
Saturnina P., pictured center, is the leader of the group called Mujeres Solidarias. This group has taken out three loans together and successfully repaid them all on time. Now they are looking to take out their fourth loan to continue growing their businesses.

Saturnina is the 40-year-old mother of three children (ages 14, 12 and 10) who runs a business selling clothes. She started her business ten years ago and has a lot of experience under her belt and has been able to find all the best places to buy her inventory. However, in order to grow her business more, she needs a loan to buy more inventory to proviD. more variety for her clients.

Saturnina’s goal is to grow her business so that she can give all of her children the opportunity to go to college and become professionals. She also wants to improve the living conditions in her house so that her family can live more comfortably.

Saturnina and the whole Mujeres Solidarias group are very grateful for the opportunities micro-loans have given them thus far. They look forward to growing their businesses even more with another loan.

loans.use: To buy more inventory to provide more variety for her clients

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Rebecca is forty – five years old. She is married and has given birth to four children, two sons and two daughters. All of her children are still in school. Rebecca says she works very hard to support her husband to provide for the family. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Dunkwa in the Central region of Ghana. She is a trader. She runs a provision store in her community. She buys her goods from Kumasi. Rebecca has been in this very business for barely a year now and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy provision

loans.name: Cielo Group

texts.es:
Mirna de Jesús N. P., Santiago José P. y Juana Isabel V. son los tres integrantes del grupo Cielo, quienes pertenecen a la comarca Las Pilas, originaria de la ciudad de Masaya.

La coordinadora del grupo es Mirna de 38 años de edad, quien desde hace 5 años se dedica a la elaboración de ropa de todo tipo; Vestidos, camisas, pantalones, ropa para niño, entre otros. Inició su negocio trabajándole a una señora que importaba la ropa a honduras, pero le pagaba muy poco puesto que ella le proporcionaba los materiales.

Cuando conoció ADIM, pudo invertir en materiales y de esa manera ganar más al vender sus piezas. Los obstáculos más grandes que ha enfrentado son las dificultades que actualmente afectan Honduras, por lo cual ha tenido que abrir nuevo mercado. No obstante, no teme seguir adelante y está iniciando en el comercio nacional para vender sus mercancías.

Su crédito pretende invertirlo en la compra de materiales para continuar su negocio y ofertar variedad de productos.

Juana trabaja vendiendo verduras de manera ambulantes y Santiago vende ropa por encargo y de manera ambulante; ambos en la ciudad de Masaya.
texts.en:
Mirna de Jesús N. P., Santiago José P., and Juana Isabel V. are the three members of the Cielo (“Sky”) group. They come from the Las Pilas region and are originally from the city of Masaya. Mirna is the group’s coordinator. She is 38 years old, and for the last 5 years has made a living making all kinds of clothing: dresses, shirts, trousers, children’s clothing, etc. She started off in this business working for a woman who exported the clothing she made to Honduras, but the woman paid Mirna very little because she supplied Mirna with the materials. Once Mirna began working with Kiva partner ADIM she was able to invest in materials and thus earn more when she sold her products. The biggest obstacles she has faced are the difficulties that are currently affecting Honduras, and that is why she has had to start selling for a new market. Nevertheless, Mirna is not afraid to get ahead, and so she is beginning to sell her merchandise locally. Mirna wants to use her loan to purchase materials so she can continue with her business and offer a variety of products. Juana works selling vegetables as a street vendor, while Santiago sells clothing to order--also as a street vendor. Both of them work in the city of Masaya.

Translated from Spanish by Christopher Knutson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing raw material to continue with her business and diversify her products

loans.name: Nadine

texts.fr: Nadine est née vers les années 1982 à Cotonou, Capitale Économique de la République du Bénin. Nadine est mariée et mère de deux enfants. Nadine vit avec sa famille à Cococodji non loin de Cotonou. Nadine vend des fromages (de la marque, la vache qui rit) aux vendeuses de pains de Cococodji. C’est à Lomé, Capitale du Togo, pays frontalier du Bénin que Nadine achète ses cartons de fromages. Nadine a besoins de plus de moyens financiers qu’elle en possède actuellement pour répondre efficacement à la demande de sa clientèle. C’est la raison pour laquelle Nadine sollicite de crédit auprès d’ALIDé.
texts.en:
Nadine was born around 1982 in Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Benin. She is married and the mother of two children. She lives with her family in Cococodji, not far from Cotonou. Nadine sells cheeses (the brandname Laughing Cow) to bread vendors of Cococodji. Lomé, the capital of Togo (a nation bordering Benin) is where she buys boxes of cheeses. She has need of more financing than she currently possesses for responding appropriately to customer demands. This is Nadine's reason for requesting an ALIDé loan.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 40 boxes of cheeses

loans.name: Akua

texts.en: Akua is sixty years old. She is married and has given birth to eight children, six sons and two daughters. Some of her children are still in school while others are learning trades. Akua works very hard to support her husband to provide for the family. She lives with her husband and children in a family house in Dunkwa in the Central region of Ghana. She is a trader. She trades in all kinds of foot wears for ladies. Akua buys her goods from Kumasi and sells at the local market. She also hawks and treks to other towns to sell. She has been in business for ten years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy foot wears

loans.name: Edmundo

texts.es: Edmundo tiene 26 años, es un joven muy tranquilo y trabajador, vive en la casa de sus padres, a quienes desea brindar una vejez tranquila. El persistente trabajo está dando frutos, el restaurante que con tanto esfuerzo puso, cada día tiene más clientes. Y es que “El Mordisco”, que es como se llama su restaurante, es uno de los lugares más concurridos, debido a la buena atención que brinda, pero sobre todo, la deliciosa sazón que tienen sus comidas. Lo que más le gusta a Edmundo de su trabajo es atender a sus comensales, ya que es el administrador del restaurante. Lleva 2 años en este negocio y considera que lo más difícil es satisfacer a sus clientes y brindarles un buen servicio, ya que las personas son muy exigentes, aun así sabe que ese es su trabajo y que tiene que cumplirlo. Para un futuro cercano espera que su restaurante crezca y se convierta en uno de los más conocidos de la ciudad. Este es el primer préstamo de Edmundo con MFP, sabe que tiene que pagarlo a tiempo, puesto que no quiere causarle problemas a las socias de su banco comunal. Con los mil nuevos soles solicitados comprará nuevas sillas y mesas para mejorar el ambiente de su restaurante.
texts.en:
Edmund is 26 years old. He is very easy going and is a hard worker. He lives in a house with his parents, who hope to have a peaceful old age. His persistent work has begun to pay-off. The restaurant that he worked hard to establish is attracting more customers each day. It is that “El Mordisco” (The Nibble), which is the name of the restaurant, is one of the busiest places because of their good service but more importantly because of the delicious taste of the food. What Edmund likes the best about his work is attending to his diners while he manages the restaurant. He has been working in this business for two years. He considers the most difficult part to be satisfying his customers and bringing them good service. People are very fussy. Even so he knows that this is his work and he has to do it. In the near future he hope that his restaurant grows and that it becomes one of the most well known restaurants in the city. This is the first loan Edmund has had with MFP. He knows that he must make his payments on time because he would not want to cause any problems for the members of the community bank. With the 1,000 new soles that he is asking for he will buy new chairs and tables in order to improve the environment of his restaurant.

Translated from Spanish by Esther Levandoski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: He will purchase furniture for his restaurant.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Tamansane Group

texts.en:
This is Samuel I. K., Augusta K. and Nanah K., who named their group Tamansane. This is not the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva. With the help of previous loans, they were able to expand their businesses. However, having repaid their last loan successfully, they are again requesting a new loan of Le 900,000 each to help them further improve their businesses.

Samuel I. K. (middle) is the leader of this group. Samuel is a photographer. With this loan, he will buy two cartons of film and sell to colleagues at the studio. A carton of film cost Le 400,000 in Freetown.

Samuel was born in Makeni city, thirty-four years ago. He is married to a businesswoman and they have five children. Samuel’s children are still young and are attending primary schools.

loans.use: To invest in his business

loans.name: Juan Carlos

texts.es: El señor Juan Carlos Hernández de 39 años de edad, reside en el barrio Memorial Sandino en la capital de Managua,  trabaja como contador  en la alcaldía, lleva veinte años trabajando a mucho esfuerzo para poder salir adelante con su familia. Su meta es poder  dar educación a sus hijos. Con este préstamo es su quinto ciclo en Afodenic el cual va invertir en la compra de materiales de construcción para hacer un por porche  y poder darle a su familia una mejor comodidad. Da las gracias a ala institución por los beneficio de poder hacer las mejoras a su casa ya que solo por el financiamiento puede hacer estos logros.
texts.en:
Juan Carlos is 39 years old and lives in the Sandino Memorial Community in the capital city of Managua. He works as an accountant for the city. He has twenty years of experience working in this business that has allowed him to improve his family’s life. His goal is to provide an education for his children. With this loan, which is his fifth one with Afodenic, he would like to buy materials to build a porch for his family and thus provide them with a more comfortable life. He gives thanks to this institution for the benefit of being able to improve his house. Only with this loan would he be able to achieve this goal.

Translated from Spanish by Esther Levandoski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy materials to build a porch for his house.

loans.name: Essi Mawuli

texts.fr: Cette femme a ouvert dans son quartier Adidogomé à Lomé une boutique de prêt-à-porter pour subvenir à ses propres besoins. Elle exerce cette activité depuis deux ans et sa boutique est très fréquentée non seulement par les gens du voisinage mais aussi par des clients venant de loin. La plupart de ses commandes viennent d’Europe à cause des exigences de sa clientèle. Pour faire une nouvelle commande, elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter des balles de pantalons moulant pour dames, mais aussi des chemises à la mode et des produits cosmétiques de différentes catégories pour dames. Elle n’est pas mariée et est sans enfant.
texts.en:
This is a woman who opened a ready-to-wearing clothing store in her district of Adidogomé in Lomé in order to support herself.  She has been in this business for two years.  Her store is very busy, not only with people in the neighborhood, but also with customers from afar.  Most of her orders come from Europe because of customer requirements.  To order anew, she's requesting a WAGES loan to buy bales of form-fitting pants for women, and also stylish blouses and cosmetic of various types for women.  She is unmarried and has no children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing and cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is 62 years old. She is widowed and is the mother of five children, two of whom are still in school. She is very hardworking and supportive to her children, especially those in school.

Beatrice owns and operates a grocery shop and sells items like sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, skimmed powdered milk and biscuits (cookies), etc. in her neighborhood. She has been in this business for eight years now. It has been her dream to expand by adding other foodstuffs to her existing products.

With the loan, she wants to purchase more crates of assorted drinks, bags of sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, boxes of biscuits, etc. to increase her inventory. She hopes to improve her savings to support her children’s educational needs.

loans.use: To buy more cartons of assorted drinks, bags of sugar, cartons of bottled mineral water and boxes of biscuit, etc.

loans.name: Emilia

texts.en:
Emilia is sixty-five years old. She is widowed and has given birth to eight children: four sons and four daughters. All of her children are out of school. Emilia says she works very hard to be able to provide for her family. She lives with some of her children in a rented apartment in Dunkwa in the Central Region of Ghana.

Emilia is a trader and runs a provision store in her community. She has been in business for four years now. She buys her goods from Kumasi and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy goods in bulk to expand her business

loans.name: Ericka De Los Angeles

texts.es: La señora Erica de los Ángeles de 39 años de edad, casada, con tres hijos un par de gemelos de  12 y 3 años de edad, los gemelos están estudiando, reside en el barrio Memorial Sandino, su esposo trabaja como conductor en las rutas que día a día transportan a miles de Nicaragüense que abordan a sus trabajo. Doña Erica con mucho esfuerzo para ayudar en su hogar tuvo la iniciativa de comenzar a vender ropa para ayudar a su esposo con los gastos, lo cual inicio con ahorros y luego con préstamos en Afodenic, lleva diez años en las altas ventas de ropa y cosmético, con este préstamo lograra invertir en la compra de ropa variada, cosméticos para ofertar a sus clientes y captar nuevos cliente, vende al contado y al crédito. Da las gracias a la institución por los beneficios que hasta ahora ha logrado. A futuro espera seguir mejorando su casa.
texts.en:
Erica de los Ángeles is 39 years old, and is married with three children. She has a pair of 12-year-old twins, and a 3 year old; the twins are studying. She resides in the Memorial Sandino neighborhood. Her husband works as a conductor on the routes that transport thousands of Nicaraguans daily to their jobs. With much effort and in hopes of helping in her household, Erica took the initiative to begin selling clothing to help husband with expenses. She began this business with savings and later with loans from Afodenic. She has sold large quantities of clothing and cosmetics for ten years, and with this loan she will be able to invest in the purchase of assorted clothing and cosmetics to offer her clients, and this will also help her acquire new clients. She sells for cash payments or on credit. She thanks the Afodenic institution for the good that she has accomplished to date. In the future she hopes to continue making improvements to her home.

Translated from Spanish by Mariela Cedeno, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase assorted clothing and cosmetics.

loans.name: Ayaba Viako

texts.fr: Cette dame est veuve et a à sa charge 03 enfants. Depuis la mort de son mari, il lui est difficile de subvenir aux besoins de sa famille. Pour cette raison elle s’est lancée en 2008 dans la vente de serviettes, de draps et d’habits à Lomé dans le quartier d’Agoè Sokpossito. Elle n’a plus de stock ; pour cela elle voudrait avoir un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 50 paires de serviettes, 10 paires de drap et 10 bals d’habits de seconde main de toute sorte.

loans.use: Achat de serviettes, de draps et d'habits

loans.name: Brenya

texts.en:
Brenya is 27 years old. He is single and currently lives alone. He is a dealer in mobile phones, phone housings and accessories. He also provides repairs and servicing for his customers. He says the sale of mobile phone has become very lucrative business in Ghana because almost every Ghanaian desires to possess a mobile phone for easy and fast communication.

Brenya buys his supplies from importers at wholesale prices and sells to his customers at retail prices. He requests the loan to enable him to procure an increased stock of mobile phone and accessories. He hopes the loan will enable him to increase his savings and expand his showcase.

With the loan, Brenya believes he can buy assorted phones so that his customers can make a better choice from them. He would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy an increased stock of mobile phones and accessories

loans.name: Latifatou

texts.fr: Latifatou est née en 1952 à Ouidah au Sud du Bénin. Latifatou est veuve et mère de cinq (05) enfants tous à sa charge. Latifatou vend des bijoux et tissus Basins qu’elle exporte vers le Gabon, pays voisin du Bénin. C’est à Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin que Latifatou achète ses tissus et bijoux. Pour augmenter sa capacité d’exportation de ces articles, Latifatou sollicite un prêt de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Latifatou was born in 1952 in Ouidah in southern Benin.  She is a widow and the mother of five children who are all in her care.  Latifatou sells jewelry and damask cloth that she exports to Gabon, a country neighboring Benin.  Dantokpa, the grand  international marketplace of Benin, is where she purchases her fabrics and jewelry.  To increase her export capacity of these items, she is requesting a loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ten 5-meter bolts of rich damask cloth and some jewelry to sell

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en: Patricia is forty – nine years old. She is widowed and has given birth to five children, two sons and three daughters. All of her children are still in school. She says she works very hard to be able to provide for the family. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in Dunkwa in the Central region of Ghana. Patricia is a trader. She runs a provision store in her community. She buys her goods from Kumasi. She has been in business for twenty years now and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy provision

loans.name: Janorys Paola

texts.es: La joven Janorys de 20 años de edad,  junto con su mama se dedica a la venta de perecederos como, plátanos lo cual vende al por mayor, desde horas temprana se levanta para ir a trabajar al mercado donde día a día poder logra tener mejores venta. Reside en el barrio Enrique Smith, soltera, lleva ocho años en el mercado el Mayoreo una Terminal en la capital de Managua, pues ayudaba a su mama en las ventas. Ahora ella tiene su propio tramo y a futuro espera lograr montar otro para obtener mejores beneficios. Con este préstamo comprara plátanos a mayor cantidad para lograr buenas ganancias y también poder dar a buen precio a su clientela, da las gracias a la institución por que logrado mantener su negocio debido al incremento de su inventario y por la oportunidad de administrar su propio negocio.

loans.use: Comprar platanos en cantidad para seguir vendiendo al mayor

loans.name: Patricio López Group

texts.es:
El grupo Patricio L. está integrado por tres mujeres, de presencia muy alegre, dinámica y humilde, que son Jazmina del Carmen G. Guitan, Marisol del Socorro L. y Irma del Carmen M. G.; Originario de el barrio Camilo Ortega de la Ciudad de Masaya. 

La coordinadora del grupo es Jazmina, una joven ARTESANA de 25 años de edad, que aún que de presencia muy sencilla, es de carácter muy osado y ambiciosa en su trabajo.
Jazmina trabaja desde hace 15 años en la elaboración de sombreros bordados, alfombras, canastas a base de palma y Cabuya (Fibra textil extraída de la penca o mamey con la que se fabrica cuerdas y tejidos) y en la manufactura de ropa con bordados típicos Nicaragüenses. 

Éste oficio lo aprendió de su madre, quien desde que tenía 10 años le enseño como elaborar éste tipo de artesanías. Jazmina alega que al ver que los ingresos eran buenos, decidió independizarse para poder ganar su propio dinero. Actualmente es madre de 3 niños a quienes quiere enseñar el oficio y al mismo tiempo desea que ellos se preparen para formar una empresa de éxito.

Su crédito pretende invertirlo en la compra de mayor cantidad de materiales, para no tener que viajar tan seguido, ya que éstos se compran en zonas como Somoto y Santa Lucía (Lugares totalmente alejados de la Ciudad de Masaya). Está preparando mercadería para la época más alegre del año, que es la celebración de la Purísima (Nicaragua entera celebra a la inmaculada Concepción de María).

Irma Muños vende ambulante productos como lo son (Zapatos, cosméticos, bisuterías entre otros) y Marisol L. trabaja en la elaboración de artesanías a base de palmas (Trenzas, chis chiles, canastas).
texts.en:
The Patricio Lopez Group is composed of three women, very happy, dynamic and humble in appearance. Jazmina, Marisol and Irma are from the Camilo Ortega neighborhood in Masaya, Nicaragua.

The coordinator of the group is Jazmina, a 25 year old artisan, who despite her very simple presence, is audacious in character and ambitious in her work. Since the age of 15 Jazmina has made embroidered hats, carpets, and baskets from palm and mamey fibers, from which she weaves cords and fabrics. She also makes typical Nicaraguan embroidered clothing.

She learned her trade from her mother, who beginning 10 years ago, taught her how to do this type of craft. Jazmina says that upon seeing that the earnings were good, she decided to become independent in order to earn her own money. At present, she is the mother of 3 children to whom she wishes to teach the craft and at the same time, she wants them to form a successful enterprise.

She intends to use her loan to buy a larger quantity of materials, so that she won't have to travel so often, since they are only available in zones like Somoto and Santa Lucia (places far outside Masaya). She's preparing merchandise for the happiest time of year, the celebration of the Immaculate Conception of Mary.

Irma sells products such as shoes, cosmetics, and jewelery, among others in the street markets. Marisol, too, makes artisan goods using palm fibers (braids and baskets).

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING PRIMARY MATERIALS IN LARGER QUANTITIES

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica is a 30-year-old mother of one who sells fabrics and shoes and owns rental houses in Nairobi. Monica has been in these businesses for the past three years. Previously, she sold secondhand clothes.

Monica is requesting her first loan of Ksh 50,000 in order to increase her stock of shoes and fabrics. She hopes to one day own a wholesale shop. In the future, Monica would like to educate her son and build a good home.


About Faulu Kenya:
Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To increase her stock of shoes and fabrics

loans.name: Masan Kossiwa A.

texts.fr: Cette femme a appris la couture, mais elle n’a pas trouvé les moyens pour ouvrir un atelier. Pour aider son mari à subvenir aux besoins de leurs 03 enfants, elle a décidé en 2007 de se lancer dans le commerce de pagnes dans son quartier à Agoè Nyivé. Elle a désormais une clientèle qui lui est fidèle. Pour avoir un nouveau stock, elle sollicite un prêt de WAGES pour acheter 15 paires de pagnes Hitarget, 10 paires de pagnes Phoenix et 30 paires de pagnes Java.
texts.en:
This is a woman who learned how to sew, but she hasn't found the means to open a workshop.  To help her husband support their three children, she decided to launch a business selling pagnes (colorful West African cloth) in 2007 in her district of Agoè Nyivé.  She now has a loyal customer base.  She is requesting a WAGES loan to buy 15 pairs of Hitarget pagnes, 10 pairs of Phoenix, and 30 pairs of Java.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy quality cloth

loans.name: Marian Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the Marian Group, named after the group’s leader. They are requesting a loan of Le 1,200,000 for each to help them further improve their businesses. With the help of this loan, they can buy more goods to add into their businesses, make better sales, more profit and consequently improving on their standard of living. Thus they will be able to give better support to their children in terms of feeding, clothing, and educating them.

The leader of this group is Marian C. (left). Marian was born in Magburaka town, in northern Sierra Leone. She is age forty-five, married to a businessman and they have two children. Marian’s children are still attending schools; one is in Senior Secondary School II and other is in Senior Secondary School I. Marain sells local produce like rice, palm-oil, pepper, gari (food made out of cassava), cucumbers and so on. She has been a businesswoman since 1984.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Jem Erick

texts.es: El joven Jem U. tiene 27 años de edad, docente de secundaria, por las mañana da clases y por la tarde es cadete de taxi, lo cual es de mucha ganancia ya que sus meta es poder tener su propia casa para cuando se formalice, vive junto a sus padres en el barrio Reparto Shick, en la capital de Managua. Como plane quiere pode terminar su carrera, desde joven trabaja ya que le gusta tener su propio dinero, con el préstamo en Afodenic lo quiere para comprar black y Cigüeñal para un vehiculo que tiene propio pero que esta en mal estado, lo cual generara muchas ganancia cuando lo ande  trabajando, da las gracias a la institución por el logro de hacer mejoras a su vehiculo ya que traerá beneficios.
texts.en:
Jem U., 27, is a high school teacher. He teaches classes in the mornings. In the afternoons he drives a taxi, which gives him good earnings. His goal is to be able to have his own house when he starts out on his own. He lives with his parents in the Reparto Shick neighborhood in the capital of Managua. As a plan, he wants to be able to complete his career. He has worked since he was young, and he likes having his own money. With the loan from Afodenic he wants to buy a crankcase cylinder. He has his own vehicle, but it is in bad shape. He earns a lot of income from the vehicle when working. He is grateful to the institution for being able to fix his vehicle because it will bring him benefits.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a crankcase cylinder to give his customers good service

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is divorced and has three kids, all of whom are in school in the community where they live. She is 49 years old and runs a clothing shop where, for the past four years, she has sold jeans-clothes, blouses and skirts, women slippers and dress-bags. She mostly sells through hawking (going door-to-door) in the nearby communities during their market days.

As a single mother, Elizabeth is constrained by funds to run her business and to meet her family needs in the way she expects. She needs the loan to inject more working capital into her business to scale up her business progress. She believes the loan will help her to be more resourced to purchase a large quantity of good quality items to upgrade her inventory. She says she would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To purchase more jeans-clothes, ladies' wear and slippers

loans.name: Ivania Group

texts.es:
El grupo Ivania está formado por Ana Julia S. H., Ivania Balladares C. y Petrona del Socorro G. B.. Tres mujeres originarias de la comarca José Dolores B., ubicada en la ciudad de Masaya.

Ana Julia trabaja en la elaboración de artesanías bordadas con su hija de 19 años, doña Ana inicio su negocio desde hace 5 años, impulsada por su hija, quien había aprendido a bordar y motivo a su mamá a trabajar en conjunto. Ana corta las piezas y su hija hace los bordados. Esto les ha ayudado a generar más ingresos ya que Ana solamente trabajaba en la elaboración de comida los fines de semana. Así su hija hoy está estudiando en la universidad y pretende superarse.

El crédito lo invertirá en la compra de materia prima para ir ampliando el negocio, sueña contener un tramo en el mercado de Masaya donde puedan ofertar directamente sus trabajos a los turistas y clientes que visitan el lugar.

Ivania trabaja en la elaboración de tortillas y posee una mini pulpería que desea ir ampliando; Petrona vende ropa usada y elabora comidas por las noches.
texts.en:
Ana Julia S. H., Ivania Balladares C., and Petrona del Socorro G. B. make up the Ivania group. These three women are from the José Dolores B. region, which is located in the city of Mayasa. Ana Julia makes embroidered handicrafts with her 19 year old daughter. Ana started the business five years ago. Her daughter learned how to embroider, and she encouraged Ana to work with her. Ana cuts the pieces, and her daughter embroiders them. This has helped generate more income because Ana used to only work at making food on the week ends. Her daughter is now studying in the university, and she is trying to improve herself. The loan is to buy raw material to expand her business. She dreams of having a place in the Masaya market where she could sell her work directly to the tourists and customers who go to the market. Ivania makes tortillas. She has a small mini market that she wishes to expand. Petrona sells used clothes, and she makes food in the evenings.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy materials to meet the demand

loans.name: Mensah Ahouaga

texts.fr: Cet homme a appris comme métier l’imprimerie. Ceci lui a permis de mettre sur place depuis 1993 dans son quartier TOGO 2000 à Lomé son atelier d’imprimerie. Il est marié et cette activité lui permet de subvenir aux besoins de ses 02 enfants. Il a besoin actuellement d’acheter des papiers rames ; pour cette raison il sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 20 cartons de papier rames. Les grandes entreprises et sociétés de Lomé constituent sa clientèle.
texts.en:
This is a man who learned the trading of printing.  This enabled him to establish his print shop in 1993 in his district of TOGO 2000 in Lomé.  He is married, and this business allows him to provide for his two children.  He currently needs to buy reams of paper;  for this reason, he's requesting a WAGES loan, so as to buy 20 boxes of paper in reams.  The major enterprises and companies of Lomé constitute his customer base. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy printing paper

loans.name: Karla Estebana

texts.es: La señora Karla Rodríguez de 48 años de edad, reside en el barrio Villa Reconciliación en la capital de Managua, su negocio es una pulpería que desde hace nueve años administra la cual logro poner con ayuda de su esposo, ahorros y luego con prestamos, procreo seis hijos tres de ellos mayores y casados y los otros estudian, su esposo trabaja en una ferretería como conductor, doña Karla desde horas temprana  se levanta para preparar el desayuno de su familia y para dar un buen servicios a sus clientes ya que abre la pulpería bien temprano, tiene la ventaja que sus hijos le ayudan ya que en horas de la mañana las ventas son buenas. Con este préstamo comprara granos básicos, productos lácteos, y carnes, para ofertar a sus clientes, y brindarle un mejor servicio. Agradece a la institución ya que a través de este financiamiento incrementa su inventario, lo cual genera mejores ganancias.
texts.en:
Karla Rodríguez is 48, and she lives in the Villa Reconciliación neighborhood in the capital of Managua. She has a mini market that she established nine years ago. She was able to do this with help from her husband, savings, and then with loans. She has six children. Three are grown and married, the others are in school. Her husband works as a driver in for a hardware store. Karla gets up very early to make breakfast for her family and to give her customers good service. She opens the mini market very early. She has the advantage of her children helping her; sales are good in the morning hours. She will use the loan to buy basic grains, dairy products, and meat, in order to give her customers better service. She is grateful to the institution because she is able to increase her inventory with this loan. This will generate more earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy basic grains, meat, and dairy products

loans.name: Kodjo

texts.fr: Ce monsieur est marié  et a à sa charge 02 enfants. Il a appris la couture ; il exerce cette activité depuis 2001 dans son quartier Gbégnédji à Lomé. Il a un nombre élevé de clients, car confectionnant de très bons habits. Il voudrait avoir un crédit de WAGES pour acheter une machine de surfilage et des tissus pour  perfectionner sa couture, mais aussi pour coudre des habits à vendre à sa clientèle.
texts.en:
This is a gentleman who is married and has two children to support.  He learned how to sew and has been in this business since 2001 in his district of Gbégnédji in Lomé.  He has a large number of customers because he makes very good clothing.  He would like to obtain a WAGES loan to buy an overcasting machine and some cloth to perfect his tailoring but also to sew outfits to sell to customers. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy an ovecasting machine and some fabrics

loans.name: Progress Group

texts.en:
Comfort is 29 years old trader she is married and mother of four children. All her children are currently in school. She is a very resourceful mother whose hard effort brings livelihood to the family. She supports her husband in taking care of the family through the sale of used clothing sales. Selling of used clothing has a very big market share in Ghana as brand new cloths are very expensive for the economically active poor and has been in this business for a year now. She travels to a nearby city called Kumasi to purchase her stock of goods. She wants to use the loan to buy more bales of used clothing to increase her inventory she normally concentrates on kid’s wear, bed sheets and used towels sales. She believes this loan would help her save for her children future and also to rent a store to trade as she sells the clothing through hawking. 

She is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Progress’. She is the one in the middle in the group photograph. Most of the members of this group are petty traders, food vendors etc. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy increased bales of used clothing and bags charcoal.

loans.name: Camelia Group

texts.es:
El grupo camelia es originario de la comunidad “Colonia Guadalupe” de la ciudad de Masaya; Las integrantes son Carolina R., Bertha E. y Flor G.. Las tres se dedican a la venta de Verduras y otros productos.

La coordinadora del grupo es Carolina, quien a sus 20 años, trabaja en la venta de Repollos, además elabora platanitos (Plátano frito, empacado en pequeñas bolsas), y elaboran tortillas. 

Este es el trabajo que realiza su familia en conjunto para poder subsistir. Iniciaron su negocio hace 7 años, cuando su mamá movida por la necesidad, decidió empezar la venta de platanitos en su casa. Actualmente elaboran mayores cantidades y los venden en los colegios, y otros centros de la comunidad. Además iniciaron la venta de repollos. Carolina dice que como familia han tenido que enfrentar situaciones difíciles, como lo es el hecho de que su hermano está muy enfermo. Pero que siguen adelante, y todos trabajan unidos.

Bertha trabaja en la venta de frutas en el mercado de Masaya; Flor trabaja vendiendo Verduras de manera ambulante en la ciudad de Masaya.
texts.en:
The Camelia group is originally from the Colonia Guadalupe neighborhood in the city of Masaya. The members are Carolina R., Bertha E. and Flor G.. The three of them work selling vegetables and other products. The coordinator of the group is Carolina, who at 20 years of age, works selling cabbage. She also makes platanitos (fried plantains, packaged in small bags) as well as tortillas. This is the work that her family does to be able to get by. They started the business 7 years ago when her mother, out of necessity, decided to start selling platanitos in her house. Currently, they make them in larger quantities that are sold in schools and other places in the neighborhood. In addition, they started selling cabbages. Carolina says that they have had to face difficult situations as a family, such as the fact that her brother is very sick. But they continue ahead and all of them work together. Bertha works selling fruit in the Masaya market. Flor works selling vegetables as a street vendor in Masaya.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raw materials for businesses

loans.name: Mayra

texts.es: Doña Mayra López, reside en un bario Laureles Norte en la capital de Managua, su esposo esta en el extranjero y le envía remesas, aunque difícil ha salido adelante con sus hijos uno de 25 y 3 años, el mayor trabaja y estudia, con dinero propio de las remesa logro comprar pacas de ropa de segunda mano y palmea tortilla, lo cual hasta ahora le va bien. Sus planes es poder ayudar a sus hijos a que tengan una buena educación. Con este préstamo comprara cinco pacas de ropa, para salir a vender a los departamento ya que se vende a buen precio por ser bonitas y buenas, también comprar varios quintales de maíz ya que también entrega tortillas a los comedores, aunque trabaja duro, sabe que logra buenas ganancias lo cual se siente sastifecha por los logros. Da las gracias a la institución por el préstamo otorgado para trabajar con más inventario y dar a sus clientes un buen servicio.
texts.en:
Mayra L. lives in the region of Laureles Norte of the capital city Managua. Her husband is currently working abroad and sends her support, but eventhough she has had trouble providing for her children, 25 and 3 years old. The eldest is working and goes to school. With her own funds she managed to purchase packages of second hand clothing and she also makes tortillas by hand, and so far it she has seen success. Her plans are to be able to support her kids so that they both have a good education. With this loan she will purchase five packages of clothing, as she plans to visit stores to resell these items as they are good quality and in good condition. She would also like to purchase various sacks of corn flour so that she will continue to sell to restaurants. She works very hard and she makes a good living, and she is personally satisfied with her successes. She feels very grateful to the organization for the loan granted to her especially because she will be able to have a larger inventory to offer her clients.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase five packages of clothing and corn flour.

loans.name: Ayabavi Kafui

texts.fr: Cette dame est mariée et est mère de 04 enfants. Pour aider son mari à assurer la formation scolaire de leurs enfants, elle s’est lancée depuis 2001 dans la vente de produits génériques de toute sorte. Pour renouveler son stock de produits pharmaceutiques, elle sollicite un prêt de WAGES. Elle est très connue dans son quartier Akodessewa à Lomé.
texts.en:
This is a lady who is married and the mother of four children.  To help her husband ensure their children are educated, she got started selling all types of generic pharmaceutical products in 2001.  To renew her stock of pharmaceuticals, she's requesting a WAGES loan.  She is well-known in her district of Akodessewa in Lomé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy generic pharmaceutical products

loans.name: Miguel Angel

texts.es: El señor Miguel Ángel de 51 años de edad, reside en el barrio Laureles Norte en la capital de Managua, casado su esposa es modista y le tiene dos hijos de 5 y 18 años de edad, el desde muy temprano sale de su casa ya que trabaja en la cooperativa de buses de Managua desde hace doce años, trabajo cansado pero con la ventaja que entre mas vuelta de la ruta gana mejor, lo cual espera poder terminar de hacer su casa y poder tener a su familia en las mejores condiciones, con este préstamo es su noveno ciclo en Afodenic y va  a construir un porche para tener mas espacio y mejor para descansar por las noches. Da las gracias a la institución por el préstamo ya que se le hace difícil poder construir y con el préstamo comenzara ya.
texts.en:
Miguel Ángel is 51 years old and resides in the Laureles Norte neighborhood in the capital of Managua. He is married and his wife is a clothing designer; they have two children ages 5 and 18. He leaves his house very early, given that he has works for the Managua bus cooperative, a job that he has held for the past twelve years; it is a tiring job with the advantage that the more times he carries out his route, the more he earns. He hopes to be able to finish building his home, and to be able to provide better living conditions for his family. With this loan he will enter in his ninth loan cycle with Afodenic; he will use this loan to build a porch that will provide more space and a better place to rest at night. He thanks the Afodenic institution for the loan, given that it has been difficult for him to being construction, and with this loan he will be able to start building immediately.

Translated from Spanish by Mariela Cedeno, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase materials to build a porch.

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en: Hannah is 30years old she is single with no children and she is living independently. Life she said is a bit challenge but she tries hard to overcome most of them. She is currently into sale of earrings and necklace made with silver, copper, and gold brands and she sells them through hawking through the market. She takes stock of goods from Kumasi and retail to her customers. She requests the loan to buy earrings and to upgrade her stock. She takes delivery of goods from Kumasi. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy assorted earrings and necklace in bulk.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy is a 37-year-old mother of three who lives in, and runs her welding business in, Mihang’o, Nairobi. She is asking for her first loan of Ksh 50,000 in order to add to her stock of metal. She hopes to one day own a hardware store. She describes herself as hardworking, jovial, and as one with good character. She hopes to educate her children to the highest level.


About Faulu Kenya:
Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit-Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To add to her stock of metal

loans.name: Kokouvi

texts.fr: Cet homme est marié et est père de 02 enfants. Il exerce comme activité depuis 2003 la vente des produits d’alimentation générale. Ce commerce lui permet de subvenir aux besoins de sa famille. Sa boutique d’alimentation est très connue de tous ceux qui visitent le quartier Noukafou à Lomé. C’est pour cela qu’il sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 10 boîtes de tomates, 03 cartons de sardines, 05 sachets de pâtes alimentaires, 3 boîtes de biscuits de toutes sortes et d’autres produits nécessaires pour son commerce.
texts.en:
This man is married and the father of 2 children. Since 2003, his main business has been consisting in selling food staples. This business enables him to provide for his family. His food store is well known to all visitors of the Noukafou neighborhood in Lomé. This is why he's seeking a loan from Kiva's partner, WAGES, in order to buy 10 boxes of tomatoes, 3 boxes of sardines, 5 packs of pasta, 3 boxes of cookies, and all sorts of other products necessary for his business.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 10 boxes of tomatoes, 3 boxes of sardines, 5 packs of pasta, 3 boxes of cookies, and other products

loans.name: Flor Kantutita Group

texts.es:
Martha P.  de 39 años es integrante del grupo “Flor Kantutita” que pertenece al Centro Focal “German Busch”  y ella vende comida  hace un año, inició su negocio por la necesidad de contar con un ingreso que le ayude a cubrir los gastos de su hogar, tiene su puesto de venta en la puerta de su domicilio. Actualmente ella quiere seguir mejorando su negocio y necesita el préstamo para comprar insumos como arroz, papa y fideo. Al igual que Martha las demás integrantes del grupo también tienen sus propios negocios como la venta de telas, otras atienden tiendas de barrio, algunas tejen chompa y finalmente una vende fruta. Todas necesitan el préstamo para invertir en su negocio comprando mercadería, materia prima e insumos. 

“Flor Kantutita” está compuesta por 11 integrantes y están juntas hace aproximadamente un año , actualmente la presidenta es la señora Martha P..
texts.en:
39-year old Martha P. is a member of the ‘Kantutita Flower’ group, a part of the German Busch centre. She began selling food a year ago because she needed an income to cover household costs. Her stall is located in the doorway of her home. Martha now wants to improve her business and needs a loan to buy ingredients such as rice, potatoes, and noodles. Similarly, the other members of the group have their own businesses. Some sell material; some have stores in the neighbourhood; others knit sweaters; and one woman sells fruit. They all need money for their businesses: to buy merchandise or ingredients. The Kantutita Flower group is composed of eleven members who have been together for approximately one year. Their president is Sra. Martha P..

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy merchandise and ingredients

loans.name: Perpetual

texts.en:
Perpetual is 38 years old. She is married and the mother of five children; all are currently in school. She is a resourceful mother who works very hard to provide food and support for her business. She is a petty trader and sells at the community market square. She enjoys selling, the business through which she makes a living. She sells items like cooking oil, pepper, spices, earthenware pots, and poly bags, etc. on top of a table in the market.

Perpetual buys her stock of goods from the Kumasi central market, in a nearby city, and from her surrounding communities for the vegetables. She is requesting the loan to upgrade her inventory. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy tomatoes, spices, peppers, cooking oil, poly bags, etc.

loans.name: Peris

texts.en:
Peris is a 32 year-old mother of three who runs a tailoring shop in Kayole. She has been in this business for the past year and a half.  Peris is requesting her first loan fo Ksh. 20,000 in order to purchase a overlock machine and materials. In the future, she would like to have a cloth manufacturing business. Peris hopes to one day build a home for her family, and educate her children. 



Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable micro-finance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: Buy overlock machine and add stock of materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy boxes of sardines, tomatoes, cookies, and various other goods

loans.name: Esperanza Group

texts.es:
El Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras es un programa desarrollado por la Fundación Paraguaya en donde un grupo de señoras con diversas actividades económicas se juntan para solicitar un crédito y se comprometen solidariamente a pagarlo. Estos créditos son destinados exclusivamente a la inversión en sus negocios o actividades comerciales.

Estas señoras son mujeres que además de atender a sus hijos y esposos, trabajan para poder aportar con el ingreso familiar. La voluntad de superación de las mismas es admirable y es por eso que Fundación Paraguaya decide apoyarlas y capacitarlas para poder lograr erradicar la pobreza.

Las integrantes de este comité se dedican a las siguientes actividades:

Patricia P..	Venta de mercería
Maria O..	Copetín
Zlly A..	Venta de joyas
Haidee A..	Despensa
Apolonia S. Ojeda	Venta de caramelos 

Cynthia P..	 Venta de bebidas
Cynthia A..	Manicurista
Josefina A..	Venta de ropas
Angelica P..	Venta de reciclaje
Antolina S..	Venta de bebidas
Isabel A..	Modista
Liz P..	Costurera
Juliana C..	Venta de carteras
Marcia A..	Modista
Ada N..	Manicurista
texts.en:
The Committee of Enterprising Women is a program developed by the Paraguayan Foundation in which a group of women engaged in diverse economic activities get together to request a loan and commit themselves in solidarity to pay back the loan. These loans are exclusively destined to be invested in their businesses or commercial activities.

These women, in addition to caring for their children and husbands, work to be able to contribute to the household income. Their will to get ahead in life is admirable and because of this the Paraguayan Foundation supports and prepares them in hopes of eradicating poverty.

The committee members dedicate themselves to the following activities:

Patricia P.. Sale of sowing wares. Maria O.. Snack bar. Zlly A.. Jewelry sales. Haidee A.. Small grocery store. Apolonia S. Ojeda Candy sales. Cynthia P.. Drink sales. Cynthia A.. Manicurist.
